keyTakeAways: Two confirmed cases of mpox in California — one in Long Beach and one in Los Angeles County — may represent the first instances of local transmission of a different variant (clade I) of the virus in the US.
Both infected individuals were hospitalized and are now recovering at home; no clear link between the cases has been established.
Public health officials emphasize that the risk to the general public remains low, and no evidence of ongoing community transmission has been found so far.
The virus, also known as monkeypox, is related to smallpox and can cause fever, chills, body aches, and painful skin lesions, especially in more severe cases.
Clade I mpox differs from the 2022 clade II outbreak in that it spreads through various forms of contact and affects a broader demographic, including children in Africa.
A new variant of clade I has spread in eastern and central Africa; the WHO declared it a public health emergency but later downgraded it due to reduced transmission.
Local health departments in Long Beach and Los Angeles County are investigating, and some close contacts have received the Jynneos vaccine.
The ongoing federal government shutdown and CDC layoffs have weakened public health response capacity, raising concerns about delayed or impaired outbreak responses.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Two cases of clade I mpox have been confirmed in California — one in Long Beach and one in Los Angeles County — potentially marking the first instances of local transmission of this virus variant in the U.S. Health officials state that the risk to the public remains low and no evidence of community spread has been found. The cases are not linked to travel abroad, and close contacts have been vaccinated. While the virus is rare and similar to smallpox, its broader transmission pattern in Africa raises concern, especially given that the ongoing federal shutdown and CDC staff layoffs have reduced public health response capacity. Experts warn that the emergence of local transmission could signal a growing threat, particularly as the virus spreads through various forms of contact, not just sexual activity.
title: California mpox cases raise concerns. But health officials say the risk remains low
